thread.title: John Boehner says he'll remain speaker until House finds replacement
thread.title_full: John Boehner says he'll remain speaker until House finds replacement | The Columbus Dispatch

author: The Columbus Dispatch
title: John Boehner says he'll remain speaker until House finds replacement
text:
WASHINGTON - Less than a half hour after House Majority Leader Kevin McCarthy dropped out of the race for speaker, Speaker John Boehner said he was “confident” McCarthy had the votes in the GOP caucus and in the House. 

“I’m confident he’ll win today and I’m confident he’ll win on Oct. 29,” Boehner told Ohio reporters in a half hour long interview Thursday immediately before a scheduled GOP caucus vote on the next speaker. 

But a half hour later, McCarthy told a stunned group of GOP colleagues that “it wasn’t his time,” and threw the speakership into question again. 

Boehner abruptly canceled the vote. 

In a written statement Boehner released after the McCarthy news broke, he said, “As I have said previously, I will serve as Speaker until the House votes to elect a new Speaker. We will announce the date for this election at a later date, and I’m confident we will elect a new Speaker in the coming weeks.”
>> Photos: John Boehner over the years   

>> Sign up for the Dispatch Politics newsletter for all the latest news 

Boehner, a fastidious man who once listed his hobbies as “cleaning his apartment,” insisted Thursday that he wasn’t frustrated to leave behind a GOP caucus in disarray. 

“There’s never a good time to leave,” he said. “There’s always something hanging out there.” 

He admitted that the Congress is far more polarized than it was 20 years ago. 

“The Congress reflects their constituents,” he said, “and as we’ve watched over the last 20 years people were getting hundreds of times more information about their Congress than they ever got before…it’s tended to pull or push people into one or two camps, leaving fewer people in the middle.” 
  
jwehrman@dispatch.com
